children.subject: Could we also get the time? For instance, Sunday, May 17th at what time?
I was unable to find the specific time, but I'll ask the instructor and post his answer here.

The official time we've been going with so far is 11:55 PM EDT (Eastern Daylight savings Time).

We may or may not decide to push that back a little bit (which would make it technically an early-AM EDT time on the day after the one listed on the schedule), but let's go with what I just said for now, and we definitely won't make it any earlier than that.
Thank you professor.
Does the "Quiz X" mean "Udacity Quiz"?

While I don't know this for certain, I believe that they will not be the quizzes on Udacity. In the Spring 2015 version of Assignment 2 (link here), the quiz questions for that week were included in the assignment. When the students took a quiz, they merely saved their answers in a .txt file and uploaded them on T-Square They may follow that format this summer, or they may post the quizzes themselves on T-Square and have us answer the questions there. I'll ask the instructor and when I have more information I'll post it here.

These are not the Udacity quizzes - those "quizzes" are just for you to test yourself and will not be graded.

The quizzes that will be graded will be given online. We are decoupling them from the project assignments this semester, so they will be given separately. (Basically, there was no reason to put them together if the questions are not about the assignment. Some assignments this semester may or may not ask you to answer questions about the assignment, but those are not "quizzes" and will be part of the assignment grade, not the quiz grades.  This also allows us to have the quizzes and projects due on alternating works, to smooth the workload for both you all and for the TAs.)

We plan to use the "Tests & Quizzes" tool in T-Square to give the quizzes - you will take them online at you convenience, within a certain time window, and they will be un-proctored and open note. However, using this tool for the quizzes is new this semester, and there's a chance we may change how they're administered if it ends up not working out well. (Although I think it will be okay, or we wouldn't be trying it in the first place.)  :)

Would it help to clarify if we called them "tests" instead?  I think the word "test" implies a longer length and greater portion of the grade than these will be (or at least than each will be individually). On the other hand, it would avoid overlapping with Udacity's terminology, in which "quiz" means something else.

Just my opinion, it would be great if we can get two or more tries on the tests. 

I know for a fact other classes give more than one try on their tests which was helpful.

I am not sure the reason but most likely because internet can do unexpected things.

I personally like the way they did things from the previous semester such that we were not pressured by short time to take the quizzes.

I think calling it anything that doesn't imply it's a Udacity quiz would be useful - such as "mini test" or "t-square quiz". Also, how long can we take with them? A few minutes, a few hours or a few days? In the latter case, you should just call them homework :)
Thank you professor, Brad, Myung and Daniel.

We used the T-Square quiz function in CS6440 in Spring and that worked out very well. It was a one and done and we had an hour to finish once we started it. We had about a 3 day window from when it was made available and when we had to do it, but again, was on a one hour timer once we started. No stopping and coming back to it. It worked quite well in my opinion for that particular class and the lecture material was available in transcripts. I could also see having the full 2 or 3 days and save and come back to it before submitting if it were a little more complex quiz or test content. Pretty sure the tool allows for that as well.

Definitely hoping we'll get at least 2 tries on the tests, in case of dropped internet connections, t-square crashing, etc in the middle of a test. Last semester we used the timed t-square tests for the final exam in CS6475, while the format worked well, t-square was slow during peak hours and some people's exams crashed/got kicked off in the middle of their first try.
I have a wedding this weekend so I need to submit this homework before thursday. I do not see it as an assignment yet in T-Square, when will it be up?
I believe the assignments are submitted through the Udacity portal.
Timothy. I don't believe that is correct. See the assignment and various piazza posts. I think T-Square just isn't ready yet.

I'm flying out today and won't be back until late Sunday, so what I'm going to do is email the files to myself and then keep checking for when T-Square lets us upload the files - and then do it from the road on my laptop connected through the wireless sharing on my phone while traveling down Highway 40... if necessary.
The assignment can now be submitted via T-Square.

Just to check, when will we be having the office hours ? Is it on a weekly basis and at what time ?

Do we have one this week.
Somewhere it was posted that offices hours would start in week 2.
ok

Sam is correct.  It's mentioned on the course Wiki on Udacity:

"We will be holding office hours online starting in the second week of class, details TBA. (We will _probably_ use WebEx.)"
Sorry if I've missed something obvious - but where do I find the "lessons"?  We are supposed to be covering Lesson1 and 2 this week, but I've been unable to find what that entails.
The lessons are just referring to the video lectures on Udacity.
Thanks Shipra.

Week 10Lesson 11Quiz 5 (Lessons 10-11)Sunday, July 19 @ 11:55 PM EDT
Week 11(none)
Finals(none)Project 6 (no final exam)TBA
